The CV response of [NiAmben] obtained in the range of potentials between −0.9 and 1.3 V in the DCE-based electrolyte ( Figure 4a) shows a well-defined oxidation peak at 0.11 V, followed by two partially overlapping waves at peak potentials of 0.60 V and 0.76 V, and another oxidation peak at 1.05 V. The single reduction wave is broad and better pronounced than the one observed in EC/DEC. The voltammogram of the complex recorded in the potential range from −0.9 to 0.25 V ( Figure 4b) displays a pair of well-defined oxidation–reduction peaks ( E pa(I) = 0.11 V, E pc(I) = −0.13 V at 0.05 V s −1) with quite large peak-to-peak separation Δ E = 240 mV. The oxidation appears to be chemically reversible. The I p

forward relationship does not depend on the scan rate in the range 0.005–0.05 V s −1 ( Figure 4b), which indicates that the first oxidation of [NiAmben] in DCE could be coupled with reactant adsorption at the electrode.
